article:
The easy way out isn't always the easiest.  I learned that lesson when I decided to treat Doug, my husband of one month, to a special meal.  I  _  to make homemade bread.  Knowing the bread would take time, I  started on  it as soon as Doug left for work.
As I was not  _  in cooking, I thought if a dozen was good, two dozen would be better, so I  _  .everything. As Doug loved oranges, I also opened a can of orange and  _  it all into the bowl.  Soon there was a sticky dough covered with  _  yellowish marks.  Realizing I was  _  ,I put the dough in the rubbish bin outside so 1 wouldn't have to  _  Doug laughing at my work.  I went on preparing  the rest of th  _  ,and when Doug got home, we sat down to Cornish chicken with  rice.  He tried to enjoy the meal but seemed  _  Twice he got up and went outside, saying he heard a  _  .
The third time he left, I went to the window to see what he was doing. I saw Doug standing about three feet from the  rubbish bin  ,holding the lid up with a stick and looking  _  When I came out of the house, he dropped the stick and explained that there was something  _  in our rubbish bin.  Picking up the stick again, he held the lid up  enough for me to see.  I felt  _  .But I stepped closer and looked harder. Without  _  it was my work.  The hot  _  had caused the dough to double in size and the  fermenting yeast(})made the surface.  _  and sigh as though it were breathing.
I could see why Doug was shaken.  I had to admit what the"  living thing  "was and why it was there.  I don't know who was more  _  by the whole thing---Doug or me.
